doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson's Transcript of a Letter From Thomas Woodrow to Jessie Woodrow Wilson dated 19 Oct. 1855

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: Copy, made by Woodrow Wilson himself, in one of his record books, of a letter written at Worthington, Ohio, on October 19, 1855, by Thomas Woodrow (Woodrow Wilson’s grandfather) ,to his daughter, Janet (Woordrow Wilson’s mother);
My dear Daughter,
I send you according to my promise a copy of an extract which I made from the Register of Baptimsms in England before my leaving the country.
Carlisle, June 22nd. 1835
True extract from the Register of Baptisms belonging to Annetwell St. Chapel, Carlisle, England. Extracted by me
Thomas Woodrow-formerly pastor
of the Church assembling in such Chapel, Carlisle, June 1835
I certify the above to be a true copy taken from the original by me this day. Worthington, Oct. 19, 1855
* Died at Carlisle, aged 8 mos.

note.p: Transcript of a copy of a letter; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Joseph R. Wilson, 16 Dec. 1888

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: My thoughts are full of you and dear ‘Dode’ all the time. Tennessee seems so far away for a chap as hungry as I am for a sight of the two men whom I love. As the Christmas recess approaches I realize, as I have so often before, the pain there is in a season of holiday and rejoicing away from you. As you know, one of the chief things about which I feel most warranted in rejoicing is that I am your son. I realize the benefit of being your son more and more as my talents and experience grow: I recognize the strength growing in me as of the nature of your strength: I become more and more conscious of the hereditary wealth I possess, the capital of principle, of literary force and skill, of capacity for first-hand thought; and I feel daily more and more bent toward creating in my own children that combined respect and tender devotion for their father that you gave your children for you. Oh, how happy I should be, if I could make them think of me as I think of you! You have given me a love that grows, that is stronger in me now that I am a man than it was when I was a boy, and which will be stronger in me when I am an old man than it is now—a love, in brief, that is rooted and grounded in reason, and not in filial instinct merely—in love resting upon abiding foundations of service recognizing you as in a certain very real sense the author of all I have to be grateful for I bless God for my noble, strong, and saintly mother and for my incomparable father. Ask ‘Dode’ if he does not subscribe? And tell him that I love my brother passionately.

We have had about there months of continuously bad weather here and are proportionately ‘under the weather’ with various forms and degrees of cold; but fine cold days have come at last and we are one and all getting on our feet again. Will get used to this villanous climate by-and-by, doubtless.—I have been wondering whether the Burney house is snug and dry in winter. I sincerely hope the rigors of the Clarksville weather may not get at you in it.—We are expecting Ellie’s cousin, Mary Hoyt, to come up from Bryn Mawr to spend the holidays with us.—Ellie joins me in unbounded love to you both.

note.p: ALS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Harper and Brothers, 25 Sept. 1896

Header.copyright: Copyright 2005 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

Header.abstract: Woodrow Wilson is writing to his publishers about the proofs for his book on George Washington

docBody.p: I write to ask if you will not be kind enough to send me revised proofs of so many of the pages of my “George Washington” as have been cast. The book ought, of course, to have an index and I ask for these proofs in order to set about making one at once.
Will you not be kind enough to send me a line with the proofs to say whether the numbering of the pages now cast is to remain the same after the illustrations shall have been inserted?

note.p: The text “ans and complete proof sent Sep 28. 1896" is handwritten in the upper left hand corner of the first page.
ALS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Harper and Brothers, 1 Oct. 1896

Header.copyright: Copyright 2005 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

Header.abstract: Woodrow Wilson is writing to his publishers about not receiving the proofs for his book on George Washington

docBody.p: I received the proofs which you were kind enough to send me the other day and shall press the making of the index forward as rapidly as may be possible amidst my other engagements.

I was very much surprised to find the second half of the book already cast.– and I must confess also not a little chagrined. You will remember, (though somebody has evidently forgotten,) that I wrote to you when I sent the copy for the second half of the book, asking that you would send me the proof of that part before the pages were cast; and you replied promising to do so.
I must ask you to send me still another set of the proofs for this second half to be corrected, for I must keep these I have for the making of the index.

I am disturbed to find that, at any rate, not all of the corrections, which I made in the proofs of the first half have been made in the plates. I have noticed several where the copy was not followed, and where the correction is necessary to the sense. Am I right in concluding that this proof which has been sent me was printed before the plates were corrected? I suppose of course I must be; but I ask because of my very great desire to see the rest of the book as perfect as I can make it.

note.p: ALS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Dorr E. Warner, 18 May 1897

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: I am interested to hear of your application for the position of Assistant Principal of the State Normal School of Montana; and am quite willing that you should use my name as a reference in regard to your character and standing while in college. I remember your conduct as beyond reproach, and your class work as faithful and intelligent.
Mr. A. L. Stone,
My Dear Sir,

It gives me pleasure to say that Mr. Dorr E. Warner was a pupil under me here, and that he made upon me the impression of a diligent student and an upright man. I should think it thoroughly worth your while to give careful consideration to his application for a place as teacher in your State Normal School.

ps.p: P. S. You do not give me Mr. Stone’s address. I therefore enclose my letter to him.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson: Fragment of Manuscript or Speech on Education, [between 1902 and 1910?]

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: blem of crowds and of the loss of this vital contact. How can even the genius of the born teacher avail to lead and quicken so many? How shall he find the time, where shall he find the place and the opportunity to get intimate access to indivviduals in so great a multitude?

The English universities solve the problem by their division into colleges, — or, rather, their division from the first into colleges, in each of which only a comparatively small number of undergraduates can live, enabled them to avoid this loss of the teacher amongst the crowd. Each college is a little community apart, a little academic family in which there can be no daily intimacy between teacher and pupil; and nowhere, probably, in all the academic world, is the contact between the two more natural, more constant, more influential than there. The masters of Baliol have been the foster fathers of generation after generation of men who have been awakened to the highest achievements alike of scholarship and of public service in their day. And nowhere better than in the English colleges can the part which the personality of the teacher plays in education be studied, — the deadening effect of intercourse with teachers who make their teaching a mere routine and have no spark either of enthusiasm or of natural energy with which to make themselves potent to the stimulation of the students entrusted to their care, — and the quite incalculable stimulation of intimacy with teachers fitted to be guides, eager to be guides, and showing at every step a loving familiarity with fair regions of learning and of science, — good companions, good counselors, lovers of young men and of all that quickens and informs their spirits for the work of the world. A great tutor will beget in the men he touches and energy and worth of faculty which goes to the depths of character as well as of achievement.

The personal factor in education is the chief factor. For the young it is necessary, in order that they may that they get the real zest of learning into their hearts, that learning should live in their presence in the person of some man or woman whom they can love and must admire; whose force touches them to the quick, they scarcely know how, whose example they cannot shake off or forget, whose spoken word they cannot dismiss, whose written words even, though they be seen after many years, when the sound of the voice, the gesture, the glance of the eye have been lost, bring back upon the instant all the old magic like a recreative touch, a rebirth of the very person. No system of teaching which depends upon methods and not upon persons or which or which imageines the possibility of any substitution of the written word for the living person can work any but mechanical mechancal effects. The teacher’s own spirit must with intimate and understanding touch mould and fashion the spirit of the pupil: there is no other way to hand the immortal stuff of learning on.

note.p: This manuscript may be related to the preceptorial system of education or the quadrangle plan for student housing, both innovations enacted while Wilson was President of Princeton University from 1902 to 1910.
TMS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

docBody.p: Mr. P. I. McElroy, of our graduating class, has been under my instruction for two years and I am glad to recommend him as a man of sterling worth whom I should expect to show unusual intelligence and thorough trustworthiness in whatever he should undertake.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Thomas C. Elder, 13 Dec. 1902

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: I very much appreciate your thoughtful kindness in sending me the address on “Private Business Corporations in Virginia,” which you this year delivered as President of the Virginia Bar Association. The subject is of real interest to me, and I shall take pleasure in reading this address during the first leisure that offers.
With much regard,

note.p: TLS: Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to W.M. Jackson, 13 Jan. 1903

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: Allow me to thank you very warmly indeed for your letter of January 10th. I do not know any praise of my History that I would rather hear than that which you bestow, that it is at once frank and just, and certainly there is no region from which I would rather have that praise than from the South. One of my chief objects in writing the History was to do justice to the region in which I was bred and which I love, the region which, I think, also I understand and can without presumption speak for. I am indebted to you for a warm act of kindess.

endnote.p: Wilson is referring to his 5-volume work A History of the American People, published in 1902.
The word “that” is interlined in ink.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to L.L. Campbell, 20 Jan. 1903

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: I am very sorry that I am about to leave town and have not time for an extended reply to your letter of January 16th; but you will find a very satisfactory account of the establishment and operation of our honor system by a member of our Faculty in the first number of Harper’s Weekly for June 1895, and I am sure that every member of the Faculty would tell you that since that time as before its adoption, it has had entire and unqualified success. We are more proud of it than of anything else in the University.

endnote.p: These changes are marked in pencil.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Mrs. Christian S. Baker, 20 Apr. 1903

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: Mr. Williams brought me your letter of April 11th, and I have read it with the greatest interest and appreciation. What you recall of the early days of my father’s residence in Staunton is very vivid, and makes for me very delightful reading.

My father’s last years were somewhat painful because there came with old age a thickening of the arteries, which resulted in a slow clogging of the action of the organs, and resulted finally in blood poisoning; but he kept to the last his fine spirits, and his mind was at no time in the least clouded.
My dear mother died in 1887, and during the latter part of his life my father had moved rather restlessly from place to place because his children were all married, and his home broken up.
I wish very much that he had been able to see these lines of yours before he went; it would have cheered him very much to know how he was remembered, and to have the old days recalled.

note.p: Photocopy of TLS; original in the Wilson Letters, Library of Virginia.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to A.M. Frazer, 11 Nov. 1903

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: I fear that you must often have wondered why I did not reply to your kind letter of June 29, which I found awaiting me on my return from Europe. I hope that you have divined the true reason. I have waited in the hope that I might see my way clear to accept the very attractive invitation which it conveys.

The deeper I get into my work as President of Princeton, however, the more unmistakably apparent it becomes that I cannot undertake addresses of the character which you suggest. Only an historical discourse would be suitable for the occasion for which you are planning, and I know perfectly well that it would be impossible for me to write an address of that kind.

I have come to this conclusion with the greatest regret. I have a feeling of most loyal affection for Virginia and for the place of my birth, and I know that it would have gratified my father very much to have me undertake a service of this sort. I hope that you will be kind enough to let me know the date you finally fixed upon for the celebration, in order that I may if possible at least give myself the pleasure of being present.
With much appreciation,

note.p: Facsimile of TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to A.M. Fraser, 20 Oct. 1904

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: I had promised myself with a good deal of confidence that I could attend the Celebration of the Church which you are planning for the 30 October; but I now find to my great disappointment that official duties will keep me at home.

I know how great a pleasure I am missing, and I assure you that I am acting against my inclination. Pray express to the Committee in charge of the Celebration my warm appreciation of their invitation and my sincere regret at being obliged to decline.
With much regard,

addrLine.name: The Rev. Dr. A. M. Fraser.

note.p: Facsimile of TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Hamilton Holt, 27 Feb. 1906

bibl.CollectionName: Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library Woodrow Wilson Collection

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: The Preceptorial system is still in its stage of adaptation and I fear that it is a little too soon to say anything confidently about its results; or rather, while we can say quite confidently that it has succeeded, it is a little too early to describe it as a system in actual operation.
I appreciate your letter of the 24th and should be glad at some time to supply The Independent with an account of our results.
With much regard-

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Cary N. Weisiger, 27 Mar. 1910

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: Sunday afternoon

I had hoped to have the pleasure of calling upon you, to express my warm appreciation of Mr. Hill’s and your delightful courtesy in sending me the magnificent bunch of roses which I found awaiting me here last evening, with the greetings so graciously conveyed by your note in the name of the Virginia Society. I cannot think of any greetings that would have given me deeper pleasure; and I am sorry that callers and engagements kindly made for me by Mr. Davis have deprived me of leisure to call.
Please express to Mr. Hill my lively appreciation and believe me, with cordial regard,
3744 Westminster Place

note.p: A handwritten note in the upper left corner of the envelope reads, “From Woodrow Wilson in his own hand”; the postmark date on the envelope is 27 Mar. 1910.
ALS; WWPL. Woodrow Wilson Collection.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Charles M. East, 11 Dec. 1910

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: Absence from home and extraordinary pressure of engagements have prevented my replying sooner to your kind letter of November 30th enclosing resolutions of the Woodrow Wilson Democratic Club of Staunton. I beg that you will extend to the members of the club my warmest thanks. It gratifies me very deeply that they should form so high an estimate of my character and abilities, and it is partivcularly delightful to me to be so judged in my native City.
May I not bid the club “God-speed” in its work for the success of the Democratic party, and now I believe rejuvenated to render the country a great service if wisely guided.
With much respect,
Mr. Wilson left before letter was written.

endnote.p: Signature was made with a stamp.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Guy H. Woodrow, 18 July 1911

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

Header.abstract: Governor Woodrow Wilson arranges to meet with his cousin Guy H. Woodrow and a friend.

docBody.p: Thank you for your letter of July fifteenth. I shall look forward with real pleasure to seeing you and the gentlemen whom you are to accompany.

I presume you will reach this part of the country on the twenty-first. That day and the day following I shall be at the Governor’s Cottage, DSea Girt, N.J. On the twenty-second the first regiments arrive in Camp for annual encampment. They begin to arrive about 1 o’clock in the day and it woulbe best for you and your friend to see me earlier in the day on Saturday, if you cannot see me at Sea Girt on Friday.
I maintain my office here in Trenton only during the earlier part of the week.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Jessie Wilson Sayre to Lloyd S. Woodrow, 22 Aug. [1911?]

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

Header.abstract: Jessie Wilson Sayre tells her cousin Lloyd S. Woodrow about an attempt by Democratic State Committee chairman James R. Nugent to break up a meeting in which he was going to be forced to resign.

docBody.p: We all enjoyed your letter very much and we hope we shall see you both soon again. It would indeed be fun to visit Columbus, not only to learn to drive a machine but to see the rest of your family, too, but I am afraid there is no immediate prospect of our being able to do so.

Did you see in the paper about the exciting happenings in the hotel Coleman a week or two ago where Nugent our Democratic State Committee chairman attempted to break up the meeting that was forcing him to resign, with a dozen or more thugs from New York and Jersey City? You remember he gave a public toast to father as a “liar and an ingrate”, which the Committee wouldn’t stand for. When he thought the quorum was successfully broken up he departed, and at that critical juncture an old member from South Jersey who had been delayed by blocked cars sauntered in, the quorum was again complete, and Nugent’s fate sealed. Meanwhile the Coleman House had seen some sharp hand to hand fighting.
The encampment is over now, to our sorrow. We miss all the life and motion. But Sea Girt continues cool and delightful.
Your father cannot be as sorry as we that we missed him that last evening. However the Rumson Road ride was so delightful that we can never forget that, and so I hope he will forget the fish.
With kindest regards from us all to him and the to you all

note.p: ALS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Ernest Harvier, 7 Nov. 1911

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: Our campaign here being finished, your kind letter of October twenty-fourth lies before me. I have read your forecast of the result in New York with the greatest interest and shall watch the returns with curiosity to see just how much they yield of what you expect. The forecast certainly seems to me a most sound one.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Guy H. Woodrow, 27 Nov. 1911

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

Header.abstract: Governor Woodrow Wilson thanking his cousin Guy H. Woodrow for the Thanksgiving flowers.

docBody.p: Thank you sincerely fror your letter of the twenty-first. It came while I was absent on a short vacation and I have just returned.
It is very kind of you to tyhink of sending Mrs. Wilson and the girls flowers for Thanksgiving and I am sure they will be warmly appreciated. I telegraphed the address to-day.
With warm regards to all,

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Ellen Axson Wilson to Guy H. Woodrow, 4 Dec. 1911

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

Header.abstract: Ellen Axson Wilson thanks cousin Guy H. Woodrow for the flowers he sent for Thanksgiving.

docBody.p: I hope you will pardon my almost inexcusable delay in thanking you for the wonderful box of flowers. I was overwhelmed with visitors and engagements during the Thanksgiving recess and really could not get a moment at my desk.

Then on Monday, I found to my dismay, that you had not given me your address on your card, and I waited until my daughter’s return from Phila. thinking she would have it. But alas! she does not know it either so I must write your general delivery back! And neither has Mr. Miller sent any address w with his superb flowers.
If this reaches you, and my note to him miscarried, will you be so good as to tell him for us how very deeply we appreciate his beautiful gift and his kind thought of us.

As for the box from you I never saw any so gorgeous in the way of flowers! They came, just as they should, on Thanksgiving morning, and in perfect condition.—The ice even unmelted. You never saw such an excited household. We were all “perfectly crazy” over them,—as the girls say. The house was abloom, when we had them all arranged. The pink and white chrysanthemums were wonderful, and we are all quite sure that the yellow roses were the most beautiful flowers we ever saw. They kept so well too; we only had to throw them away yesterday. The chyrsanthemums are of course still fresh. In short we do not know how to thank you adequately for your truly magnificent gift. The girls join me in heartfelt thanks, and warm regards to all. Mr. Wilson is away—as usual.

note.p: ALS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Ernest Harvier, 18 Dec. 1911

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: Personal.

Thank you for your letter of December eleventh. I feel that Mr. McCombs is much better able to handle the matter you write of than I am, and I would be heartily obliged if you would confer with him. I warmly appreciate your thoughtfulness in giving us these inside points.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Ernest Harvier, 16 Jan. 1912

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: I have always found your analysis right so far and I dare say you are right again in your letter of January fifteenth. I think it will be sufficiently understood everywhere that I stand for polcicies which cannot be controlled by the interests you speak of, and whenever it is necessary I will make that very clear.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Guy H. Woodrow, 7 Feb. 1912

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

Header.abstract: Governor Woodrow Wilson refuses his cousin Guy H. Woodrow’s invitation to come to Ohio for the Constitutional Convenction.

docBody.p: I wish that it were possible to visit Columbus and I am sincerely complimented that the Constitutional Convention should desire to have me come, but I am firmly of the opinion that it is not right or wise for me to “invade” Ohio.
I, nonetheless, appreciate your kindness in writing.
In haste,

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Charles Catlett, 14 May 1912

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: It was thoughtful and generous of you to send me your correspondence with the Speaker of the House. It is certainly a most extraordinarty thing that he should condescend to solicitation of that sort. I have had evidences from other parts of the country that the same thing was going on elsewhere. I cannot believe that such methods will succeed. They will only be resented by all honorable men liek yourself.
With warm appreciation of your reply to him and of your kindness to me,

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Ellen Axson Wilson to Mrs. P.Y. Walker, 17 May 1912

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: I am distressed to have left your sweet letter so long unanswered, especially in view of the fact that it comes to me from an Infirmary. But really it has not been my fault, dear; After being perfectly well,—all of us,—throughout the extraordinarily long hard winter, I have had constant, though not really serious illness—in the family ever since my return from Georgia, and it has been impossible to keep up with my mail. Finally I made things worse by falling and spraining my hand! I am just able to use it a little again with much pain, so please excuse this short scrawl.

I was concerned indeed to hear that you had been having first ill health and then an operation, but apparently I ought to send my congratulations as well as my sympathy, as it is to be a case of “alls well that ends well.” I hope that you can and will write me that you are perfectly restored by this time. It was good to have even stolen fleeting glimpse of your husband but I can’t tell you how glad I should have been to have seen you with him.

I am going to try to get off tomorrow the long promised picture of myself,—a better one than that reproduced in the papers. It was taken at the same time,—just a year ago. I shall also send one of Jessie. I have more of the other two girls now, but you have doubtless seen those in the papers. Some very charming ones taken last Spring have been reproduced a good deal. Believe me, dear, with much love your friend as always

note.p: ALS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Cary N. Weisiger, Jr., 12 July 1912

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: I beg to acknowledge with the warmest appreciation your kind message of congratulation. Such evidences of generous feelingg give me great gratification.
Mr. C. N. Weisiger, Jr.,

note.p: TLS; WWPL. Woodrow Wilson Collection.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Jessie Wilson Sayre to Guy H. Woodrow, [21 July 1912]

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

Header.abstract: Jessie Wilson Sayre tells her cousin Guy H. Woodrow for his telegrams about Woodrow Wilson receiving the Democratic nomination for President.

docBody.p: I have been given the pleasure onf answering both your dear telegrams. Neither Mother nor Father were willing to leave it to secretaries, for we want to tell you personally how much we appreciated your remembering us and telegraphing such beautiful messages.

I remember how cheerful and confident you were last summer about the final outcome when to us girls at least it seemed a very far away, dire, possibility. And now it has really happened! It seems almost unbelievable.

You must be very proud of the way Ohio did in the primaries and of the fine support the Wilson men in the delegation gave us. Of course we were not in Baltimore but the tales that have come to us of events in the front of battle are so thrilling that I don’t see how we could be more excited even if we had been there.

Today Champ Clark and two hundred Democratic Congressmen are here to shake hands. It was fun meeting them and to here them sing afterwards an amusing adaptation of a camp meeting song “He good enough for Alabama—and so on down the states—and he’s good enough for us.” I wish you could all have been here to see the fun.
With kindest regards from us all for your whole family,
Saturday.

note.p: The letter is undated but postmarked 21 July 1912.
ALS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to McQueen S. Wightman, 22 Aug. 1912

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: Thank you warmly for your letter of July twelfth. It was delightful to hear from you. Mrs. Wilson and my daughters join in the warmest messages. It was fine to read a translation of the editorial. It seems strange to have people I do not know and who are at so great a distance, interested in my political fortune.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Guy H. Woodrow, 4 Sept. 1912

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

Header.abstract: Woodrow Wilson turns down an offer to stay with his cousin, Guy H. Woodrow, during his campaign to prevent jealousy.

docBody.p: RECEIVED AT NO. 44 East Broad Street, Columbus, Ohio
276 NY Y 61 NL
Guy H Woodrow C

Greatly appreciate your kind thought of me but have found throughout my campaigns that it is very unwise for me to accept invitation to private houses even the houses of near relatives because of the subtle jealious sure to arise with regard to every tpublic man. Hope I shall get a good sight of you and am warmly obliged to you

note.p: The telegram has various handwritten notes and a printed stamp marked on it; see original.
Telegram; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Martin H. Wayt, 6 Dec. 1912

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: Your cable just received. I take pleasure in confirming the 28th of December, my birthday, as the date on which I hope to visit Staunton.
Would you be kind enough to communicate this decision to Mr. Cochran?
In haste, but with the most delightful anticipations of my visit to my native place,

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Lee Douglas, 11 Dec. 1912

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: You may be sure it is a deep disappointment to me that I can not be at the dinner to Joe, but there is only one way of getting home and there is no steamer until the 14th. It is literally impossible. My heart will be with you.

I cabled my affectionate contratulations. That was all that time and space permitted, and you may be sure that they were sent from a full heart. It it delightful that Joe’s friends should have honored him in that way.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to William C. Redfield, 17 Dec. 1912

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: Pray do not think that you are adding to my burdens by proposing to discuss large matters of public business. I shall be most pleased to confer with you and the gentlemen you name. It occurs to me that you might prefer to come after the House has adjourned for the Holidays. Would you kindly let me know how soon it would be convenient to have the conference? I would wish to hold it, if possible, in Trenton.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson's Staunton, Virginia, Homecoming: Program, 27-28 Dec. 1912

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: [Photograph of Woodrow Wilson]
Friday, December 27
7:50 p. m.—Arrival of President-elect and party. Torchlight Procession.
8:45 p.m.—Band Serenade and Public Speaking by distinguished speakers at the Virginia Hotel.
________Saturday, December 28
10:00 a. m.—Reception at Manse of the First Presbyterian Church to State, County and City Officials, Official Guests of the City and members of the Wilson Celebration Committee.
12:00 noon—Review of the Parade at Main Street Public School Building.
2:30 p. m.—Address of Welcome by Doctor Fraser and Response by Mr. Wilson, at Mary Baldwin Seminary.
3:00 p. m.—Public Reception at Mary Baldwin Seminary.
4:00 p. m.—Reception to Mrs. Wilson and Mrs. Mann by Ladies of the City and County at Stuart Hall.
This is the Official Program. Various other events will take place later.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Martin H. Wayt, 3 Jan. 1913

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: Thank you for your courtesy in forwarding Mr. Laird’s telegram. No apoliogies were necesssary.
Mrs. Wilson and I enjoyed more than I can say our visit to Staunton. It was in every way an ideal experience and we cannot too warmly thank you for your own gracious attention to our pleasure.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to A.M. Fraser, 3 Jan. 1913

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: We have settled again to our routine at home but it will be a long, long time before we loose the vivid impression of the pleasure we had in visiting you at Staunton. Your hospitality was of the truest, most generous and thoughtful sort, and we shall always be grateful to you for it and count ourselves among your friends and admirers. I wish there was some other way besides words in which I could express the real debt I feel under to you.

Mrs. Wilson is herself going to write to Mrs. Fraser, but I wanted to give myself the pleasure of sending to Mrs. Fraser and you and the young people of your household this warm expression of my deep appreciation.

endnote.p: Wilson misdated this letter; the correct year is 1913.

note.p: Facsimile of TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Louise Hydewrich, 6 Jan. 1913

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: It was most thoughtful and generous of you to send us the box of apples and we have appreciated them warmly indeed. It seems to complete the impression upon our palates of the delightful reception we had in Staunton.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

address.render: 88 W. state st, trenton, n. j.

docBody.p: Thank you for the letter from Dr. Barrows. You may be sure it will receive my most careful perusal and consideration.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to McQueen S. Wightman, 6 Jan. 1913

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: I wrote you last before I had seen the very beautiful and artistic presents you were generous enough to send to Mrs. Wilson and me. The bronze you sent to me I shall value most highly, both for its own intrinsic artistic merits, which are unusual, and as a souvenir of your friendship. Mrs. Wilson wants to write you a little line for herself, thanking you for the beautiful embroidered dress pattern you sent her, but in the meantime may I not send you this line of personal appreciation on my part of your kindness in thinking of both of us.
I would like very much if I could get hold of you the latter part of next week. Will you not let me know where I can telegraph to you then.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

docBody.p: Allow me to thank you most warmly for your kind letter. I appreciate it very much indeed.
I beg to assure you that the suggestion you make will be most carefully considered, and I wish to thank you for making it.

docBody.p: Begun and held at the City of Washington on Monday, the first day of December, one thousand nine hundred and thirteen.

To provide for the establishment of Federal reserve banks, to furnish an elastic currency, to afford means of rediscounting commerical paper, to establish a more effective supervision of banking in the United States, and for other purposes.

doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Hampton H. Wayt, 29 Dec. 1913

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: Thank you warmly for your kindness in sending me the message from Staunton on my birthday. You may be sure that it was deeply appreciated.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to John O. Cosgrave, 10 Jan. 1914

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: I am very much complimented by your urgent invitation that I attend the dinner of the Authors’ League of America, set for the fourteenth of February next, and wish most unaffectedly that it were possible for me to be present and show my interest and sympathy, but I have made it a point of duty to subordinate everything to my work at Washington and in pursuance of that policy have denied myself pleasures of this sort very consistently. I think that it is not right for the President to speak unless he has something to say and there is public occasion why he should say it, and this opinion of mine strengthens my scruple about accepting dinner invitations, however important and attractive.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Arthur Yager, 15 Aug. 1914

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: I thank you with all my heart for your message of sympathy. It was gracious of you to think of me in my personal grief, and I am cheered by your friendship.

note.p: Wilson’s “personal grief” refers to the death of his first wife, Ellen Axson Wilson, on 6 August 1914.
TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Arthur Yager, 15 Dec. 1914

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to John T. Wilds, 22 Dec. 1914

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: Personal
From my heart I thank you for your generous letter of the twenty-first of December. I have read it with the deepest appreciation.
Warmly reciprocating your Christmas and New Year greetings and good wishes, I beg you to believe me,

name.person: Rev. John T. Wilds, D. D.,

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Louis Edelman, 22 Dec. 1914

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: I am sincerely sorry to hear of the unsatisfactory condition of your health and hope most earnestly that you will presently find yourself very much better.

Mr. House has shown me your letter of December eighth to him and it has, of course, excited my sincere sympathy. It is so extremely difficult to find a satisfactory place in the public service without suspending the rules of appointment by examination, and it is so dangerous to suspend those rules, for reasons which I think will be obvious to you, that at present I must candidly say to you I despair of finding anything suitable. I would not be frank if I did not say this to you.
I regret very much that the public business claimed my attention so constantly while you were here that it was impossible for me to do more than shake hands with you.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Ella Young, 30 Dec. 1914

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: You must think me very indifferent to your kindness that I should have left your letter of the nineteenth of September so long unanswered. The truth is that I have felt so strongly disinclined, for reasons which I hope you will understand and sympathize with, to speak of my loss and of the dear lady who is gone that I have been weak enough in some instances, as in this one, to postpone writing even to those who I knew were her closest friends and for whom I shared her affection.

I am very much obliged to you for what you say about the picture, but I do not feel that I ought to keep the picture you speak of. I have a copy of it packed up with the things at home and I feel that you ought really to have the copy you speak of.

You may be sure that I will comply with the greatest pleasure with your request for a recent picture of Ellen. I am not thoroughly satisfied with any of them, but the one we send you is at least one of the best.
With warmest regard and appreciation,

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Guy H. Woodrow, 12 Jan. 1915

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

Header.abstract: President Woodrow Wilson refuses his cousin Guy H. Woodrow’s invitation to come to Ohio to visit the Jefferson Club of Columbus.

docBody.p: I warmly appreciate your kind letter just received and wish with all my heart that I could accept the invitation of the Jefferson Club of Columbus, but it is very obvious to me now that I must stick close to my task here in Washington until the end of the present short session of Congress. I have played truant once but it would be very unwise for me to do so again. There is too much here that needs my personal attention.
Cordially and sincerely yours,

note.p: Photocopy of TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson: Letter of Reference for Allen S. Hulbert, 14 Feb. 1915

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: 14 February, 1915.

This will introduce my young friend, Mr. Allen S. Hulbert, in whom I am sincerely interested. I am writing these lines in the hope that if Mr. Hulbert should ever be in position where, among strangers, he may need advice or friendly guidance or direction they would serve to make him known as a man earnestly in search of the place and the means by which he may make himself most useful.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Clarence J. Owens, 25 Mar. 1915

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: I am extremely sorry to say that it becomes more and more evident as the time approaches that it will not be possible for me to leave Washington to attend the Southern Commerical Congress, though I had earnestly desired to do so. Every day makes it more clear to me than it was the day before that my duty is to remain uninterruptedly here, or at most be absent a very few hours at a time.
I need not tell you how reluctantly I have come to this conclusion, but there is no escape from it.
Please express to all concerned my warm appreciation of their generous insistence on this trip and my very great regret.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Joseph P. Tumulty, 3 July 1915

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: I am heartily obliged to you for your telegrams. It is characteristic of you to keep my mind free by such messages. I am really having a most refreshing and rewarding time and am very thankful to get it. I hope that you are not having depressing weather in Washington and that you are finding it possible to make satisfactory arrangements for the family, so that we can have the pleasure of having you with us at the White House when I get back.
With warmest messages from us all,

note.p: Facsimile of TLS; original in the J.P. Tumulty Papers, Library of Congress.

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

docBody.p: Thank you for your letter of March twenty-ninth and its contents. I find it both interesting and convincing. This is just a line of acknowledgment, but of cordial acknowledgment. If I have an opportunity to speak about the inopportuneness of attaching a prohibition clause to the Porto Rican bill at this time, you may be sure I will do so.
In haste

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Joseph R. Wilson, Jr., 12 Apr. 1916

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: Of course it will be convenient for us to have you. Let us know exactly when you are coming over, and come directly to the house. If you will let us know the train, we will have you met by one of the cars.
It is delightful to look forward to seeing you.
In haste

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Joseph R. Wilson, Jr., 7 June 1916

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: The sudden rush of work has prevented my replying sooner to your letter of May thirty-first. It was delightful to have an evening with you, even though it was an evening when we could not really talk very much. The “Frolic” was great fun, I thought, and it was fine to enjoy it with Kate and Alice and you.
The box was, of course, given to us by the management.
We think of you a great deal and with deep affection.
In haste

address.addrLine: c-o U. S. Fidelity & Guaranty Co.,

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Joseph R. Wilson, Jr., 18 July 1916

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: I have your letter about Mr. T. Leigh Thompson with a copy of Colonel Ewing’s letters, and you may be sure that the name will have consideration when the choice is made. The material is none too abundant.
I just had a letter from Alice which pleased me very much.
In haste, with love from us all,

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Joseph R. Wilson, Jr., 19 Aug. 1916

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: Of course, I will be glad to have you visit Shadow Lawn. Nell has taken refuge there with her baby to escape the neighborhood of paralysis cases, but I am sure that if Kate and Alice and you go alone, she would welcome the invasion into her refuge.

It is impossible to tell even yet when we are to get away, but in any case the notification ceremonies will take place at Shadow Lawn and probably on the second. It now seems likely that we shall be up there only for that day and then be obliged to come back.
I am heartily glad you are having a real vacation and feel refreshed by it. I wonder if I shall ever have one!
In haste, with most affectionate messages from us all to you all,

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Joseph R. Wilson, Jr., 31 Aug. 1916

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: I have been so absorbed in ways that you very well understand that I have made absolutely no personal arrangements about Saturday. Please be sure to have Kate and Alice come over to lunch at Shadow Lawn at 1:15, and do make it possible to be there yourself if you can. It would add so much to our pleasure, and we should miss you so if you were not there.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to William G. McAdoo, 9 Oct. 1916

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

Header.abstract: Woodrow Wilson turns down an offer to play golf with two champions.

docBody.p: I don’t think Mr. Peabody crazy in proposing a golf foursome which should include himself, Chick Evans, Robert Gardner and myself, but I do think that I would be a fool if I went into it. I don’t care to have my golf exhibited just at this critical period of our country’s history, and I wish you would break this news to Mr. Peabody as gently as may be!
With love from us all to you all,
Affectionately yours,

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Joseph P. Tumulty to Frank A. Massie, 14 Nov. 1916

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: The President deeply appreciates the generous expressions of your letter of November 9th, and he asks me to thank you very cordially for having written him. He is kept in heart by such friendly messages as yours.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Arthur Yager, 15 Nov. 1916

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: Thank you warmly for your telegram and letter. The prospect of four more years is very sobering to me and I do not know that I feel very much elated, but I am deeply grateful to the country for showing such evidences of trust and confidence.

I agree with you that it is of the utmost importance that the Porto Rico Bill should be passed, and I think that on the whole it would be wise for you to remain in this country, at any rate, long enough to see whether its passage at the short session is possible or not.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to A.M. Fraser, 25 Nov. 1916

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: I thank you warmly for your kind message. A duty becomes a privilege when it is so generously rewarded with the confidence of the people.

note.p: Facsimile of TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Arthur Yager, 27 Nov. 1916

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: I was sincerely sorry not to see you before you left for Porto Rico. I did not know that your early departure had been planned.
I fully appreciate the importance of the Porto Rican Bill and have embodied a strong recommendation of its passage in the address which I shall make to Congress now in a few days.
I shall try to interest myself continuously in the matter until something is accomplished.
In haste, with warmest regard,

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Frank A. Massie, 26 Jan. 1917

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: Your letter of January twenty-fourth has given me a great deal of pleasure. I have time only for a line but it is a line of real gratitude.
In haste

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Brand Whitlock, 15 Feb. 1917

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: I warmly appreciate your generosity in sending me a copy of the medal struck in your honor and the very interesting portrait. I shall value them both as reminding me constantly of a friend whom I greatly value and admire. What you say about myself and the work we are all engaged in together makes me very proud and very grateful.

Things are thickening so about you in Belgium that it may not be very long before I see you again, but whether I see you or not, you will, I am sure, realize my warm friendship and the high value I place upon your own.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Guy H. Woodrow, 19 May 1917

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

Header.abstract: Woodrow Wilson expresses condolences to his cousin, Guy H. Woodrow, for the death of “Uncle Charles”.

docBody.p: RECEIVED AT NO. 44 EAST BROAD ST., COLUMBUS
145G GR 28 BLUE
THE WHITE HOUSE WASHN DC 1155A MAY 19 17
I HAVE HEARD WITH SINCERE SORROW OF THE DEATH OF UNCLE CHARLES AND WISH TO CONVEY TO ALL WHO WERE NEAREST AND DEAREST TO HIM MY AFFECTIONATE SYMPATHY

note.p: The telegram is stamped “450” and “1917 MAY 19 AM 11 17”.
Telegram; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to J.F.L. Long, 25 Sept. 1917

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: My attention has just been called to the extraordinary fact that all four of your sons have joined the Army and you yourself have joined the Home Guards. I want to send you at least this brief line to express my admiration. It is very delightful to see such evidences of patriotism and devotion to public duty.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Joseph R. Wilson, Jr., 14 Nov. 1917

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: I do not quite know what your agent in Mississippi means by the people in the Southern “sticks,” but I take leave to grant doubt whether he is wholly right in the report he makes to you. We are by no means idle about the matter of keeping the people of the country informed as to all matters concerning the war and its causes and purposes and necessities which it involves, and a recent letter from Senator Williams, who has made an extended tour of Mississippi, leaves upon me quite a different impression from that which Mr. Williams expresses. But in any case we are on the job!
In haste, with love from us all,

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Joseph R. Wilson, Jr., 15 Mar. 1918

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: I am taking the liberty of sending you a revised copy of the letter you thought of sending to Mr. Cates.
The fact of the matter is we are threading on very dangerous and delicate ground in this matter and cannot be too careful. I hope you will approve of the revision.
In great haste
enc.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Joshua W. Miles, 5 April 1918

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: The error in my income tax return to which you kindly call the attention of Mr. Tumulty in your letter of April third was, of course, an oversight. Will you not do a busy man the favor of regarding this letter as an authorization to correct the mistake and to have a computation refigured accordingly?
enc.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Swager Sherley, 11 May 1918

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: I take the liberty of writing to call your attention to a matter which seems to me of capital importance in connection with the effective conduct of the war. I mean the sum for National Security and Defense which has been placed at my disposal during the past fiscal year. I think that it is of the utmost importance that a similar fund should be put at my disposal for the next fiscal year, though in my judgment it need not be so large as the last appropriation for that purpose. I think that sum of half the amount, namely $50,000,000, would be abundant.
I think you and your colleagues on the Committee on Appropriations are familiar with the objects for which I have used the appropriation, but perhaps you will permit me to summarize them.

I have used considerable sums for the maintenance of the Food Administration, the Fuel Administration, and the War Trade Board, and for the maintenance of the proper agencies for the allocation of labor, a matter of the utmost importance and no little difficulty during this time of the general dislocation of labor throughout the country. For these objects it seems to me that the fund is no longer necessary, inasmuch as their administration has been now quite thoroughly organized and is susceptible of being maintained by definite appropriations assigned to their use in the usual manner. Of course, this method of appropriation is very preferable to any other.

Besides these objects, I have spent very large sums for the repair of ships owned by alien enemies which we took possession of immediately after our entrance into the war and which, as you know, had been deliberately damaged in the most serious way by their own crews; for the providing of temporary accommodations for the newly-created services connected with the war; for advances to the regular departments for services regularly appropriated for when it seemed unwise in the circumstances to wait until the appropriations, which would certainly be made, could be acted upon by the Congress; to provide additional facilities for the Civil Service Commission, in order that it might more nearly meet the exceptional demands of the time for clerical aid; for miscellaneous expenses connected with the very serviceable action of the Council of National Defense; and for labor matters of many sorts, investigation, mediation, the settlement of strikes, and many objects arising from time to time and impossible to foresee or calculate for beforehand. Most of these matters, also, may now be taken care of in the regular way, though similar occasions for the immediate expenditure of money may no doubt arise on a smaller scale than before.

There remains the uses for such a fund which I may perhaps characterize as continuing but incalculable beforehand. I refer to the conduct of many necessary investigations in connection with the determination of the prices which the Government is to pay and which the governments associated with us in the war are to pay;
To indispensable secret service and to confidential uses abroad;
To the very large necessities of record and information;

To the maintenance of instrumentalities both on this side of the water and the other which are doing admirable work in informing public opinion both here and there of the real aims of America, of the progress she is making in the conduct of the war, of the real facts with regard to all the larger aspects of our policy;
And to the service and guidance of all sorts of patriotic movements in the United States which appeal to the Government for its assistance, for materials wherewith to conduct their work.

Besides these things which can now be stated, the experience of the past year convinces me that there are many occasions which will arise which I cannot now even conjecture which will make it necessary that I should have a free fund at my disposal.

May I not say a word of special emphasis with regard to the work which the Committee on Public Information is doing? Mr. Creel in conducting this work is in a very special sense my personal representative. I have kept in close touch with the work that he is doing, and it has at all times been based in large part upon my advice. It has been admirably done and I think it very likely that nobody, not even those most intimately connected with the Government, are aware of the extent, the variety and the usefulness of that work or of the really unusually economical manner in which it has been accomplished, so far as the expenditure of money is concerned. I should feel personally crippled if any obstacle of any kind were put in the way of that work.

It is really impossible to outline what that work is, but if the Committee would like to know, I am sure they would derive pleasure as well as discover a most unusual and interesting piece of work if they would personally examine it.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Newton D. Baker to Woodrow Wilson, 13-18 Aug. 1918

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: August 13, 1918.
IMMEDIATE.
Mr. Phillips asks if you will look this over and let him have it back, with any comment you may wish to make, so that he may take it up with Mr. Polk this morning before the latter’s departure.
(SBM)

p.render: C A B L E G R A M

docBody.p: Received at the War Dept Aug 19, 1918. 1:15 AM.
1 COVersailles.
The Adjutant General, Washington.
Number 184August 18Confidential.
For the Secretary of War and the Chief of Staff. The following instructions have been issued by the British War Office to General Poole commanding allied forces at Archangel and Murmansk".

Paragraph 1.Your main object is to cooperate in restoring Russia with the object of resisting German influence and penetration, and enabling the Russians again to take the field side by side with their Alliesfor the recovery of Russia.

Paragraph 2.In order to effect the above object your immediate aim should be to establish communications with the Czechs, and assisted by them probably secure control of the Archangel-Vologda-Ekaterinburg railroad and the river and railroad lines of communications between Archangel and vVia Tka.

Paragraph 3.At the same time you should endeavor to promote resistance to the enemy by all means at your disposal including: A, organization of armed force to resist the Germans. B. The support of any administration which may be disposed to be friendly to the Allies. C. The affording of relief to the cic civil polpulation. D. Judicious propaganda.

Paragraph 4.According to your latesyt information the Czechs and anti-Bolshevik forces are in possession of the Ekaterinburg and the whole of the Siberian railroad from the neighborhood of Penza to Lake Baikal. It is however reported that the 6,000 Bolshevist groo troops with 60 guns are in possession of the railroad between Perm and Ekaterinburg. Though it is true that Allied forceshave actually landed at Vladivostok and more are en route, they are at present strictly limited in number in accordance with the view of the United Staetes as to the amount which they consider necessary to establish and maintain communications with the Czechs near Lake Baikal and act as an escort to an economic mission. It may or may not be hfound that these numbers are sufficient to ensure the attainment of the above objects and possibly therefore they may be increased. It is improbable however that in the near future any allied forces other than Czechs will reach western Siberia. Under these circumstances in all probability the Czech troops and their sympathizers now in western Siberia will turn eastwards for safety rather than stretch out to you via Perm and ViaTka. They may even not be able to maintain their present positions. You will be constantly informed of modifications in the above situation as they occur.

Paragraph 4 5.It will not be possible tosensend you more fighting troops this season than those already notified. Every effort will however be made to provide such arms and supplies as you may consider necessary and which it may be possible with the limited shipping available to place at Archangel before the closure of that port.

Paragraph 6.The events of the next few weeks alone can show whether, should the numbers of allied forces be inadequate, the Czechs can hold out and Russians in sufficient numbers rally to you to secure your immediate objects as in two above.

Paragraph 7.Should it become apparent that you will be unable to realize the object named in paragraph 2 you should concentrate your efforts on the object iin named in paragraph 3 and the immediate defense of Archangel during the ensueing winter months."

Paragraph 8.Further refer
ence my number 183 Mr. Stettinius informed me last night that he had submitted to French and English statement of artillery requirements for the 80 division program and ohoped for an official reply on August 21. He has reason to hope the reply will be favorable.
Copy for Secretary of War.

endnote.p: This word has been corrected in ink to read: “ViaTka”, the Russian city “Viatka”.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Arthur Yager, 20 Aug. 1918

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: I have your letter of July 30th reviewing the recent agitation in Porto Rico, which resulted in the charges already disposed of.

I am sending your letter to the War Department in order that it will be of record. You have, however, already been assured that we were entirely satisfied with the manner in which you have done your duty in these matters.
The commission which is to be sent to Porto Rico will, it is hoped, serve to clear up matters and make suggestions looking to the betterment of the economic situation.
I am,

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to John T. Wilds, 23 Aug. 1918

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: Alas, it is literally impossible for me to comply with the request of your letter just received, strongly as my heart prompts me to do so. It is most interesting to me that you should have had so long and successful a service in one church, and I hope that as the years go by your hold upon your people will be even more strengthened and the usefulness of the church even more widely extended.
Pardon this short letter, but you know how sincere my feeling is, though briefly expressed.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Joseph R. Wilson, Jr., 3 Oct. 1918

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: Thank you for having let me see the enclosed. The verses are really unusually good. Please congratulate Miss Dromgoole.
With love from all,

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Proclamation Announcing Death of Theodore Roosevelt, 7 Jan. 1919

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.H4: [ANNOUNCING THE DEATH OF HONORABLE THEODORE ROOSEVELT.]

H3.render: By the President of the United States of Amerca.

salute.render: To the People of the United States:

docBody.p: It becomes my sad duty to announce officially the death of Theodore Roosevelt, President of the United States from September 14, 1901 to March 4, 1909, which occurred at his home at Sagamore Hill, Oyster Bay, New York, at 4:15 o’clock in the morning of January 6, 1919. In his death the United States has lost one of its most distinguished and patriotic citizens, who had endeared himself to the people by his strenuous devotion to their interests and to the public interests of his country.

As president of the Police Board of his native city, as Member of the Legislature and Governor of his State, as Civil Service Commisioner, as Assistant Secretary to the Navy, as Vice-President and as President of the United States, he displayed administrative powers of a signal order and conducted the affairs of these various offices with a concentration of effort and a watchful care which permitted no divergence from the line of duty he had definitely set for himself.

In the War with Spain, he displayed singular initiative and energy and distinguished himself among the commanders of the army in the field. As President he awoke the Nation to the dangers of private control which lurked in our financial and industrial systems. It was by thus arresting the attention and stimulating the purpose of the country that he opened the way for subsequent necessary and beneficent reforms.
His private life was characterized by a simplicity, a virtue and an affection worthy of all admiration and emulation by the people of America.

In Testimony of the respect in which his memory is held by the Government and people of the United States, I do hereby direct that the flags of the White House and the several Departmental Buildings be displayed at half staff for a period of thirty days, and that suitable military and naval honors under orders of the Secretaries of War and the Navy may be rendered on the day of the funeral.
Done this seventh day of January, in the year of Our Lord one thousand nine hundred and nineteen, and of the Independence of the United States of America the one hundred and forty third.
[seal.]
By the President:

note.p: Proclamation; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to H. Walter Barnett, 18 Mar. 1919

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: I need not assure you of my sympathy with any such undertaking as that which you speak of in your letter of February 13th, but I am obliged to say in reply to your letter that I cannot permit the use of my name in association with the society of which you speak. I am debarred from doing so by the circumstance that I have throughout all the recent years of my life declined honorary association with bodies in whose affairs I could take no active part, and I could not now make an exception without giving just offense in many quarters.
I am sure you will understand and appreciate.

note.p: TLS: Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

docBody.p: We have just received, from Mrs. Lloyd George, the name of the unknown friend who sent us the interesting plate with the picture of the White House on it; and I hasten to express our very warm thanks and to assure you thart we will always value the gift, not only for itself, but as an evidenece of your generous friendship.

row.cell:
HOTEL PENNSYLVANIA, New York
2200 ROOMS - 2200 BATHS
THE LARGEST HOTEL IN THE WORLD

docBody.p: Your favor at hand, I shall be at Knoxville on the 4th unless events at Washington make the meeting unnecessary. It is possible that I may have to be in Washington next Monday (though not probably) If so I may ask you to postpone the meeting for a couple of days but I will notify you in ample time. But, as I say the Washington trip is uncertain & you need not say anything about it unless you hear further. You can address me can write: Saloon League Westerville Ohio

doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to W.H. Taylor, 11 Oct. 1920

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: It was certainly most thoughtful and friendly of you to write me your letter of October seventh and enclose Professor Derry’s generous tribute to me, which gratified me very much indeed. Allow me to thank you sincerely.
