doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Joseph R. Wilson, Jr., 23 Nov. 1920

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: Thank you for your letter of November twentieth telling me about Mr. Bland’s place at Catonsville, but my plans have gone far enough to make it evident that I must not be so far away from a great library as Catonsville is.
Do come in to see us soon. We are always so glad to see you.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Joseph R. Wilson, Jr., 3 Dec. 1920

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: I have your letter about Mrs. Summers, but I cannot do for her what she desires without breaking a rule that I have followed throughout my administration and to break which would confuse and demoralize the service. I am very sorry, but she will have to pursue the ordinary course of service and promotion.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Joseph P. Tumulty to Margaret W. Daniel, 3 Mar. 1921

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: I am returning to you, herewith, the volume of clippings, photographs, etc., left by you at the Executive offices. The President’s illness has resulted in making it very difficult and sometimes painful for him to use the pen. He therefore feels constrained to request that he be excused from writing autographs. I feel sure you will understand.
Secretary to the President.

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

p.render: during mr. wilson’s illness he was excused by thousands from sending them his autograph, and from autographing books, photographs, etc. in view of this he does not feel that he can in conscience begin the practice again, and therefore hopes that you will excuse him from complying with your request.

note.p: Printed form letter; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Clyde Shropshire, 11 Jan. 1922

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: 2340 S STREET N W
The message sent me on the occasion of my birthday by the Democratic Executive Committee of Tennessee and other Democrats from every County in the State gave me genuine pleasure.

I hope you will have some opportunity to express to all of them my deep appreciation as well as my congratulations on the prospects of the party, and on the choice of that fine Tennessee Democrat, Cordell Hull, as the head of the National Committee.
It is delightful to have such assurances of confidence and support as the message brought me.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Mrs. Victor Strasburger, 5 Apr. 1922

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: 2340 S STREET N W

Please accept my very warm thanks for your thoughtful kindness in sending me the beautiful flowers. They have brightened my room with their message of spring and brightened my spirits with their message of friendship. It was most gracious of you to think of sending them.
Thank you also for your kindness in sending me the interesting clipping which was enclosed in your note.
With most cordial good wishes,

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to A.M. Fraser, 24 Aug. 1922

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: Thank you for your letter of August twenty-third.
The inscription you suggest for the plate which is to be placed below the tablet to my Father is entirely acceptable to me, and I deeply appreciate the sentiment which it expresses toward myself.
Please express my appreciation to the Session and accept for yourself my cordial greetings and assurances of regard.

note.p: Facsimile of TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Eleanor Wilson McAdoo, 29 Jan. 1923

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: 2340 S STREET N W

At last we have seen the movie pictures, and we have greatly enjoyed them. Mother and Bertha, and Mr. and Mrs. Julian Bolling, enjoyed them with us, and we were all without exception fascinated by Mary Faith. There is a wonderful charm about the child. The glimpses the pictures gave of the house were most interesting and enable us to realize its beauty and its attractive home quality. Everything about it looks charming, and the little family group on the front steps was one of the most interesting features of the picture. I was glad to have a glimpse of Mrs. W. G. Jr., but wish that it might have been more than a glimpse so that I might really know what she looks like. The chief impression one gets from the groups is that of a very congenial, happy family. It is truly delightful to have such a visual record of you all. We had Robin Hood the same night, but the lasting impression on my mind was made not by that but by the McAdoo film. We are grateful to you for having sent it to us, but shall not be entirely content until we can come out and look at you all without the aid of a camera.

Edith unites with me in warmest love to you all, and in thanking you for the delightful glimpse (all too short) we had of you and Mac. When you come a long way to make a visit it ought to be a long visit, not a short one.
Please all of you keep well so that we may continue to have happy thoughts about you.
With a heart full of every affectionate wish,

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Colonial Dames of America, 3 Feb. 1923

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: 2340 S STREET N W

The pledge so graciously conveyed to me by Colonial Dames of America in the State of Virginia has given me deepest gratification. I feel greatly cheered and strengthened by such an unusual evidence of friendship and confidence, and beg you will convey to your associates my heartfelt thanks.

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Woodrow Wilson to Virginia Delegates to the National Red Cross Convention, 29 Sept. 1923

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library
Header.addressee: Virginia Delegates to National Red Cross Convention

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: 2340 S STREET N W

I was deeply gratified by your beautiful gift of flowers. It was most acceptable as coming from the delegation from my native State and cheered me very much as an evidence of generous friendship,—made the more enjoyable because of the generous message which accompanied it.
Pray accept my best wishes, as well as my sincere thanks, and allow me with deep appreciation to subscribe myself,

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Edith Bolling Wilson to Mrs. Warren, 2 Feb. 1931

bibl.CollectionName: Edith Bolling Wilson Papers/Woodrow Wilson Papers

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: I would love dearly to take a box as you ask for the Roxy benefit—but at the moment my budget, like the old Mother Hubbards cupboard, is bare—but I am glad to show my interest in anything the “Gray Ladies” do—by taking four seats for Thursday night—and enclose Check for twelve dollars—
With wishes for the success you covet—and personal assurances
believe me

note.p: ALS; Edith Bolling Wilson Papers, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.

doc.title: WWPLWW:1.01
doc.docDesc: Edith Bolling Wilson to Darryl F. Zanuck, 17 July 1944

Header.copyright: Copyright 2007 by the Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library

RelatedDocuments.link: This document on the Woodrow Wilson eLibrary.

docBody.p: Your letter of July 13 give me the delightful feeling that I am writing to a real friend and not a stranger–for the sincere admiration you express for my husband is evident in every sentence and that is always a straight road to my heart. So before answering the subject of your letter let me thank you for the years of effort the picture represents – the producing – editing and scoring; and also your hope that it will be in every way rewarding – and fulfill all our hopes and ambitions.

Your explanation regarding the Technicolor prints explains the delay in production that I had not before understood – for I have hoped ever since I had the pleasure of meeting Mr. Trotti to have word from you that I could see the film privately before its premier in New York – August 1st.

To that end I have remained in Washington – all of July – postponing plans with friends – until – just a few days ago I decided something had happened beyond your control to prevent my seeing the film – So I am committed to join others in New York August 1st where – as I am sure you know there are 100 seats put at the disposal of the Woodrow Wilson Foundation for the opening of the picture.

As I am an honorary member of the Foundation they urged me to come over for a called meeting and dinner they are having before going to the Wilson picture. Frankly it will be very hard for me to see the Film in these circumstances and I have not yet persuaded myself I can – but I have promised to be at the meeting, which is an unusually important one – and may go on to the theatre – for I am so eager to see it –, and yet, coupled with that uergent desire, is one of anxiety – which I know you understand. From New York I had promised to go to friends in Vermont on August 2nd. So it is not possible to accept your offer for a showing in Washington on that date or the 3rd or 4th – much to my regret.
I am delighted by what you tell me of the 5 Editors to whom you showed the incomplete version – if they praised that then we should take heart over the finished version.

Mr. Baker told me last Summer of your wish to make a tangible expression of appreciation for my help in preparting the Script and I shall be most happy to have you send a contribution toward an endowment fund for the Woodrow Wilson Birthplace Foundation in Staunton – We are fortunate in having as our President of this Foundation Mrs. Cordell Hull (her address is Wardman Park, Washington) and both she and I will appreciate your interest in this Memorial and feel it will appeal to you as a permanent and enduring testament of your personal trbibute to Woodrow Wilson –
With renewed appreciation of your devotion to this work – and most sincere hope for success in this and all future undertakings – believe me – my dear Mr. Zanuck –

note.p: TLS; Woodrow Wilson Collection, Woodrow Wilson Presidential Library.
